entry.et: Middle English trunke Anglo-French trunc, trunke, from Latin truncus trunk, torso

def.dt: :the main stem of a tree apart from limbs and roots called also bole
:the human or animal body apart from the head and appendages :torso
:the thorax of an insect
:the central part of anything
:the shaft of a column or pilaster
:a large rigid piece of luggage used usually for transporting clothing and personal effects
:the luggage compartment of an automobile
:a superstructure over a ship's hatches usually level with the poop deck
:the part of the cabin of a boat projecting above the deck
:the housing for a centerboard or rudder
:proboscis
:the long muscular proboscis of the elephant
:men's shorts worn chiefly for sports swimming trunks
:a usually major channel or passage (as a chute or shaft)
:a circuit between two telephone exchanges for making connections between subscribers
:a usually electronic path over which information is transmitted (as between computer systems)
:the principal channel or main body of a system or part that divides into branches a nerve trunk the trunk of a river
:trunk line

entry.et: probably from obsolete English trunk to truncate

def.dt: :short full breeches reaching about halfway down the thigh that were worn chiefly in the late 16th and early 17th centuries
:a transportation system (as an airline, railroad, or highway) handling long-distance through traffic
:a main supply channel (as for gas or oil)
:trunk 5b
:a bundle of nerve fibers enclosed in a connective tissue sheath
:a large traveling trunk usually with a rounded top
:a trunk suitable for use in a stateroom of a steamer
:a shallow trunk that may be stowed beneath a berth
